channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports, for AL
channel.description: The latest Form 5800.1 hazardous material reports submitted to the Department of Transportation and posted online by the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration, for AL

item.title: Report X-2025071371
item.description:
Report X-2025071371

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-07-17
  • City: BIRMINGHAM
  • State: AL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ABF FREIGHT SYSTEM, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: David Vest, 084 Operations Supervisor, contacted Safety regarding a UN1263 spill on the rear of the trailer. David Vest advised a pallet sitting on top of the damaged freight, crushing a carton on the rear of the trailer. David Vest advised the spill has leaked onto other cartons on the pallet. David Vest stated the spill is contained to the trailer and the lip of the trailer. Safety advised David Vest to place absorbent pads down to contain the spill from striking the yard. Kailee Mason with CURA was contacted for remediation. Following a site assessment, HES personnel noted one (1) damaged cardboard box containing four (4) 1-gallon pails of UN1263, with approximately one (1) gallon of product released onto cardboard boxes, the trailer floor, and concrete beneath the trailer. Upon further inspection, crews confirmed that only one (1) of the 1-gallon pails was damaged. The one (1) damaged pail was placed into one (1) 55-gallon drum for disposal purposes. HES personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted surfaces and worked them in with hand tools. Absorbent pads and cleaners were used to remove any residual product. The undamaged cargo was repalletized for continued processing and shipping by the facility. All spent absorbents, impacted cardboard boxes, and UN1263-impacted materials were collected and containerized into one (1) additional 55-gallon drum for disposal. The drums were properly labeled and staged on site for further management.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 4500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: AZXX 32104 was reported to have a smell emanating from the car. It was determined that the source of the odor was the vacuum relief valve. The valve seat was not sealing. The VRV was removed and a plug installed. OTMA for movement has been applied for by the shipper for movement.

  • Description: Forklift Driver was loading another shipment behind drums when the incident occured. Forklift Blades Extended Through the pallet punturing a small hole in the drum. The drum was immediately placed in an overpack. The spilled material was cleaned up and placed in a container for proper disposal.

item.title: Report E-2025060233
item.description:
Report E-2025060233

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-05-27
  • City: Cullman
  • State: AL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: GEMINI MOTOR TRANSPORT, L.P.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 9500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On May 27, 2025, Approximately 50-gallons diesel were released to the concrete and asphalt due to a fuel. overfill, while offloading. The release impacted asphalt and concrete on their tank pad. No storm drains or waterways are reported to be impacted by the release. A clean up contractor (Hepaco of Birmingham, AL) responded to the site to conduct cleanup activities. Absorbent material was applied the affected concrete and asphalt, using hand tools to spread and ensure absorption. The saturated absorbents were collected and containerized into (2) 55-gallon drums that were transported off site for proper disposal. On June 13, 2025, two 55-gallon drums containing non-hazardous solid waste, (diesel impacted absorbents and boom), were accepted at Clean Harbors of Chattanooga, TN for proper disposal. This was a one-time event, that was an immediate release, due to human error. Clean-up activities were completed the same day. This release has been completely remediated, and no evidence was found that suggests any significant environmental impact remains on site.
